stories.story: I remember the day I explained Schrödinger’s cat to my daughter in the old university office. She was just a teenager, curious and skeptical, and I used a cardboard box and her stuffed animal to make the paradox real. She laughed, asked sharp questions, and for a moment, I saw the same spark I’d seen in my best students. That afternoon, we walked home together, talking about possibility and uncertainty. It’s one of my favorite memories—teaching her, and learning from her in return.

There was a day, years ago, when I showed my daughter Schrödinger’s cat. We used her old stuffed animal and a box in my office. She was clever, full of questions. We talked about uncertainty, and I remember feeling proud. We walked home together, still debating. That memory always makes me smile.

I once explained a physics paradox to my daughter—Schrödinger’s cat, I think. We used a box and a toy. She was young, curious. We talked, walked home after. I remember her questions, her laughter. It was a good day.
There was a day with my daughter. We talked about a cat in a box. She asked questions. I tried to explain. We walked home. I remember her smile.
A day with my daughter. Cat, box. We talked. She smiled.
